linkTarget.anchoringText: Upon continued transgression and rising sea level, the tidal deposits give way to more marine sedimentation, which is generally composed of more massive, often structureless, sand rich sediments of the Upper T with variable and poorly sorted grain sizes because intense marine bioturbation has reworked mud into the sandy layers. The sand is frequently cemented with carbonate due to dissolution of shelly material. Of importance in the Upper T sands is the presence of glauconite of variable intensity but which can constitute up to 40% of the rock.
linkTarget.image-wrap:
Figure 1 i Examples of glauconite content in the Mariann Norte 1 cores
Figure 1 Examples of glauconite content in the Mariann Norte 1 cores

linkTarget.anchoringText: Despite the presence of light gravity oil in the Upper and Middle T sands from mud gas readings, oil staining in drill cuttings, and the mixed results of the small number of production tests conducted, the lack of potential as judged from conventional petrophysical methods, made any focused attention to the T sands a low priority. About 5 years ago, a more concerted effort on testing the Upper T sandstone began. Figure 2 shows a comparison of the mudlog and conventional logs in the evaluation of Chorongo Este 1 well, drilled in 2011 on the Tarapoa Block.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Chorongo Este 1 well showing a comparison between the mudlog gas and oil shows and the conventional wireline log

formatted-caption.caption-text: Chorongo Este 1 well showing a comparison between the mudlog gas and oil shows and the conventional wireline log

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Location of the three cores in the Upper and Middle T on the Tarapoa Block

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location of the three cores in the Upper and Middle T on the Tarapoa Block

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Mariann Norte 1 log and core interval. Note the great contrast between the Middle T and Upper T parts of the succession. The Middle T is highly laminated and stratified with many muddy interlayers, whereas in the Upper T, the clay has been homogenized into the sand by bioturbation. The Upper T also has high, but variable content of glauconite

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mariann Norte 1 log and core interval. Note the great contrast between the Middle T and Upper T parts of the succession. The Middle T is highly laminated and stratified with many muddy interlayers, whereas in the Upper T, the clay has been homogenized into the sand by bioturbation. The Upper T also has high, but variable content of glauconite

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 5 shows how bed thickness variations influence log measurements. The thicknesses of shale beds in green are constant, and the thicknesses of the sands beds in white are varied. It can be clearly seen that as the sand layer thickness decreases, the values of the resistivity, PEF, gamma ray, density, and neutron curves are suppressed.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: This diagram shows the thin-bed effects on gamma ray, resistivity, PEF, and porosity logs

formatted-caption.caption-text: This diagram shows the thin-bed effects on gamma ray, resistivity, PEF, and porosity logs

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 6 below, are shown the vertical resolution and radial depth of investigation characteristics for several well logs. There are significant differences for the volume of investigation between deep-sensing resistivity logs and density logs, which causes them to respond differently to oil bearing layers, especially when those layers are thinner than the vertical resolution of both sets of logs.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: This figure shows the vertical resolution and depth of investigation for different well logs. It is important to note that not even the most high-resolution logs such as NMR and density have sufficient vertical resolution to detect and measure the storage and flow properties of very thin hydrocarbon-bearing laminae

formatted-caption.caption-text: This figure shows the vertical resolution and depth of investigation for different well logs. It is important to note that not even the most high-resolution logs such as NMR and density have sufficient vertical resolution to detect and measure the storage and flow properties of very thin hydrocarbon-bearing laminae

linkTarget.anchoringText: As can be seen in Figure 7, the presence of sand / shale laminations less than 1 foot is very high, and in spite of the sand being oil saturated in the upper photo, the resitivity only measures average values across the interval.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Well log with core photos

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well log with core photos

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 8, is displayed a comparison between two wells where Chorongo Este 1 has a greater presence of laminations and as such the resistivity is more affected. Both wells have a comparable concentration of glauconite.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Correlation between Chorongo Este 1 and Mariann 4 A 1 with glauconite content

formatted-caption.caption-text: Correlation between Chorongo Este 1 and Mariann 4 A 1 with glauconite content

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on the core descriptions, we can see that in the Middle T is a greater presence of intercalations with less than two feet in thickness, which are not clearly reflected in the gamma ray curve, as can be seen in Figure 9.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Core description with Gamma Ray log in Middle T sandstone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Core description with Gamma Ray log in Middle T sandstone

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 10, it can be clearly seen how log values of RHOB vs. PHIN change across the different T sandstone zones of Mariann Norte 1. The Lower T zone in red shows values confined to quite a small range and concentrated in the sandstone–limestone interval as would be expected in a massive, homogeneous reservoir.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Crossplot of RHOB/PHIN by Zone from wireline logs of Mariann Norte 1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Crossplot of RHOB/PHIN by Zone from wireline logs of Mariann Norte 1

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 11 shows the core / log relationship from Mariann Norte 1. Despite the suggestion of intercalations in the GR and porosity logs in the Upper T, laminations are not visible in the cores as shaly interbeds.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Mariann Norte 1 core and log relationship

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mariann Norte 1 core and log relationship

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 12, shows the spectral gamma ray data over the cored interval of the Mariann Norte 1 well and provides additional evidence of the heterogeneity of the rock.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Mariann Norte 1 spectral gamma, log and core description relationship

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mariann Norte 1 spectral gamma, log and core description relationship

linkTarget.anchoringText: As can be seen in Figure 13 of the Mariann Norte core, the presence of oil saturation doesn’t exist over the entire interval of the Upper and Middle T sandstone.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Mariann Norte 1 logs and core description with pictures of the wáter saturation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mariann Norte 1 logs and core description with pictures of the wáter saturation

linkTarget.anchoringText: Glauconite variably affects different well logs and must be taken into account when doing petrophysical analyses. In the case of GR curves, in Figure 14, high values of gamma ray can be seen corresponding to sandy intervals (no shaly content) and also high concentration of glauconite, showing clearly the influence that glauconite can have. In this case, the GR would not meet the Vshale pay cutoff if the sand was oil saturated and hydrocarbon content would be underestimated.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Gamma Ray log with Glauconite percentage over the Upper T interval in the Mariann Norte 1 well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gamma Ray log with Glauconite percentage over the Upper T interval in the Mariann Norte 1 well

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Mariann 4 A 1 and the relation between wireline logs and mudlog with glauconite percentage

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mariann 4 A 1 and the relation between wireline logs and mudlog with glauconite percentage

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Log and Core Derscrotion from San Jose 1 well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log and Core Derscrotion from San Jose 1 well

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 17, the log and core porosity values from Mariann Norte 1 are displayed. The log neutron values are significantly higher than the measured core values because of high irreducible water saturation in the glauconite micropores.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Relationship of core porosity and neutron porosity in Mariann Norte 1 well; before and after correction

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relationship of core porosity and neutron porosity in Mariann Norte 1 well; before and after correction

linkTarget.anchoringText: Thomas Stieber Method As can be seen in Figure 18, the Upper T sandstone corresponds to a dispersed clay sequence where the presence of clay predominates as the matrix of the sand.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Thomas Stieber Crossplot of the Upper T sandstone in Mariann Norte 1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Thomas Stieber Crossplot of the Upper T sandstone in Mariann Norte 1

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 19, the values reflect a prominent tendency related the sand / shale laminations common in the Middle T interval.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Thomas Stieber Crossplot of the Middle T sandstone in Mariann Norte 1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Thomas Stieber Crossplot of the Middle T sandstone in Mariann Norte 1

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 20, the values at the upper left represent a clean, well sorted sand which is typical of the Lower T sandstone. The trend of the data towards the right reflects fine-grained laminations within the Lower T sand which are evident on logs.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Thomas Stieber Crossplot of the Lower T sandstone in Mariann Norte 1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Thomas Stieber Crossplot of the Lower T sandstone in Mariann Norte 1

linkTarget.anchoringText: An early time peak responds to dominant shale pore size and a late time peak responds to dominant sandstone pore size (Figure 21).

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: This graph of the NMR T2 laboratory measurement from a sample from the Mariann Norte 1 well shows the signature of a laminated core sample where the prominent early time peak corresponds to small grain size or shale laminae, and the late time peak is associated with large pore sizes

formatted-caption.caption-text: This graph of the NMR T2 laboratory measurement from a sample from the Mariann Norte 1 well shows the signature of a laminated core sample where the prominent early time peak corresponds to small grain size or shale laminae, and the late time peak is associated with large pore sizes

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 22, the NMR log display from the Tarapos North West 2 well is shown. It can be seen in track 3 the relaxation time across the T sand interval.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: NMR from Tarapoa North West 2 of Upper and Middle T sandstone

formatted-caption.caption-text: NMR from Tarapoa North West 2 of Upper and Middle T sandstone
